lead_paragraph: Disrupting the presidential election would be far easier than changing the outcome by computer hacking, officials say. But disruption may have already begun.

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and CHARLIE SAVAGE

headline.print_headline: Prime Danger in Vote Hack: Sowing Doubt
headline.main: Sowing Doubt Is Seen as Prime Danger in Hacking Voting System

snippet: Disrupting the presidential election would be far easier than changing the outcome by computer hacking, officials say. But disruption may have already begun....
abstract: United States intelligence officials say that Russian hackers will be unable to change outcome of presidential election, but could do damage in form of sowing doubts about legitimacy of election's results; while US voting system's security is of particular concern, officials say fact that it is relatively antiquated and decentralized make it more resilient to hacking attacks than other government systems.
